metadata.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax v. Narsee Nagjee & Co.

facts.text: The respondent is a firm carrying on business in Bombay.
The assessment relates to the year of assessment 1949-50 and the chargeable accounting period was from November 13, 1947, to October 31, 1948.
On January 12, 1953, the Income-tax Officer issued a notice on the respondent under s. 11(1) of the Business Profits Tax Act which was served on the respondent on January 21, 1953.
The respondent filed a return under protest.
The assessment was completed by the Income-tax Officer on November 30, 1953.

Against this order the respondent took an appeal to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner on the ground that the respondent was not liable to Business Profits Tax because it was beyond the period of four years limitation under s. 14 of the Act. This plea was upheld by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
The Income-tax Officer then appealed to the Appellate Tribunal and it confirmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
At the instance of the appellant a case was stated to the High Court of Bombay on two questions of law.
The High Court modified the first question and answered both questions in the negative.
Appeal to Supreme Court on certificate of the High Court.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Income-tax Officer had jurisdiction to assess the assessee firm under the Business Profits Tax Act by issue of a notice under Section 11(1) of the Business Profits Tax Act on 12-1-1953 in respect of the chargeable accounting period 13-11-1947 to 31-10-1948 without having recourse to Section 14 of the Business Profits Tax Act?
If the answer to Question No. 1 is in the negative whether the B. P. T. assessment could be considered to have been validly made?

petitioner_arguments.text: Sections 11 and 14 apply to different sets of circumstances: s.11 to original assessments where ITO believes person engaged in business and calls for return; s.14 to cases where profits escaped assessment after notice issued and no/under assessment.
No period of limitation prescribed for first notice under s.11; limitation under s.14 only after prior notice and return.
S.11 construed according to plain meaning allows notice at any time if ITO believes person liable.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Gokuldas Ratanji Mandavia v. CIT; Telu Ram Jain Co. v. CIT

respondent_arguments.text: Notice under s.11 invalid as issued more than four years after end of chargeable accounting period; ss.11 and 14 to be read together, limitation applies to s.11 inferentially.
Profits escaped assessment since no timely notice under s.11, so only s.14 applicable within 4 years.

court_reasoning.text: Ss.11 and 14 have to be read together; escaping assessment includes cases where no notice issued or notice issued but no assessment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The High Court was right when it held that ss. 11 and 14 of the Act have to be read together.

court_reasoning.text: Language of s.14 mirrors s.34(1) Income-tax Act; escaping assessment covers no notice or ineffective notice.
court_reasoning.key_observation: The legislature has adopted the language of s. 34(1) of the Income-tax Act in s. 14 of the Act and it must be considered to have adopted the construction of that section applied by the courts.

court_reasoning.text: No limitation in s.11 leads to anomaly; s.14 applies to original and escaped assessments.
court_reasoning.key_observation: It would lead to absurdity that in cases of definite information limitation applies but in belief cases no limitation.

court_reasoning.text: Hidayatullah J.: S.11 for first assessments without limit; s.14 for escaped after prior assessment; no implied limitation in s.11.
court_reasoning.key_observation: For profits which have never been brought to assessment, there would be two notices possible... Harmonious construction requires s.11 for no prior assessment, s.14 for after prior assessment.

holdings.text: Notice under s.11 issued after 4 years invalid; assessment without jurisdiction as profits escaped assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Pirojbai Contractor
precedents_cited.relevance: Escaping assessment includes no notice under s.22(2) or ineffective notice.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kamal Singh v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Escaped assessment includes cases of no notice or no assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maharajadhiraj Sir Kameshwar Singh v. State of Bihar
Chatturam Horilram Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Assessment proceedings failed due to lacuna is escaped assessment.

precedents_cited.case_name: Gokuldas Ratanji Mandavia v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Different language in East African Act; no two concurrent jurisdictions here.

precedents_cited.case_name: Telu Ram Jain Co. v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents_cited.relevance: Under Excess Profits Tax Act after amendment no limitation.

statutes_cited.name: Business Profits Tax Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Governing provisions for charge, notice, limitation on escaped assessment.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar language in s.34 for escaped assessment; accounting periods linked.

statutes_cited.name: Excess Profits Tax Act, 1940
statutes_cited.relevance: Identical to ss.11,14 but limitation removed by amendment.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal of the Commissioner of Income-tax, holding that the notice under s.11(1) issued more than four years after the end of the chargeable accounting period was invalid as profits had escaped assessment, requiring recourse to s.14 within four years.

key_quotes.text: In our opinion, the High Court was right when it held that ss. 11 and 14 of the Act have to be read together.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning linking the two sections.

key_quotes.text: the assessment which was sought to be made was without jurisdiction and the appeal must, therefore, fail.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: For the subsequent and reopened assessment there is a limit of four years, but for the assessment for the first time there is no limit.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Dissenting view by Hidayatullah J. on distinction between ss.11 and 14.
